content.value: The process of installing, updating, upgrading, and removing software using package manager tools.
content.example: Example: Installing a text editor using a single command.

content.value: In Linux, software is usually installed from trusted online sources called repositories. Package managers automatically handle downloading software, installing required dependencies, and keeping applications updated.

Package managers automatically handle downloading software, installing required dependencies, and keeping applications updated. This makes Linux software management fast, secure, and reliable compared to manual installation.
Repositories are online servers that store software packages. Linux systems download packages from repositories instead of random websites, which improves security and stability.

content.description: Updates the list of available packages from repositories.
Upgrades all installed packages to the latest versions.
